Risk Management Plan (RMP) Executive Summary below:



Executive Summary



The Risk Management Program includes an Executive Summary as required by Section 2745.3 of Title 19, California Code of Regulations and the Federal RMP Guidance. The Executive Summary provides a discussion of the various Risk Management Program elements as follows:



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 2. Stationary Source Activities 3. Regulated Substances Handled 4. Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios 5. Prevention Program 6. Five-Year Accident History 7. Emergency Response Program 8. Planned Changes to Improve Safety 9. Summary



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



It is the Three Valleys Municipal Water District's (TVMWD) policy to comply with the all of the regulatory requirements of the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP). The Miramar Water Treatment Plant ("Plant") has developed a RMP and CalARP Manual that documents TVMWD's policies pertaining to the prevention of accidental releases and emergency response. Included in the RMP/CalARP Manual are the Management System that includes the applicable operating, maintenance and response procedures, and technical studies such as the Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) and Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA).



2. Stationary Source Activities



The Plant is located at 1021 E. Miramar Avenue, Claremont, CA 91711.



Chlorine is used as part of the disinfectant process and is used to kill disease-causing pathogens, such as bacteria, viruses, and protozoans. Anhydrous ammonia is used in combination with chlorine to produce chloramines, providing a more stable disinfecting residual than chlorine alone.



3. Regulated Substances Handled



The purpose of chlorination is to disinfect water that is used by the general public (water facilities). Disinfection involves the addition of chlorine gas to the water to destroy bacteria, viruses, and other pathogens tha

t may cause harm to the public health. 



The chlorine gas system at the Plant uses a vacuum regulator installed at each online container to reduce the gas to a vacuum. The vacuum is produced by an injector placed in the water flow that draws in the gas. If the vacuum is interrupted, the vacuum regulator will automatically close, thereby greatly enhancing the inherent safety of the system. 



The one-ton chlorine cylinders are delivered by a truck from the vendor and are offloaded from the truck to the chlorine area. The chlorine cylinders are stored inside the chlorine building. 



The process consists of the following major equipment and facilities:



- Up to eighteen (18) chlorine containers (2,000 lbs chlorine each)

- Vacuum Regulators

- Chlorinators

- Injectors



All chlorine equipment is located within the chlorine building. Plastic tubing delivers the chlorine vapor to the chlorinators. The injector injects the chlorine gas at three locations; two for the water to effluent and one to the pond.



The chlorine building is equipped with a chlorine detector manufactured by Capital Controls. The chlorine detector alarms in the control room. The plant operator monitors the chlorine system from the control room on a continuous basis. Operator rounds are also made every two hours. The operator monitors the following variables:



- Chlorine flow

- Status of chlorinators

- Status of chlorine detectors

- Chlorine scales



Anhydrous ammonia is delivered by a truck from the vendor and is then pumped from the truck to a receiving vessel with a 1,000 gallon capacity. The system is situated inside the ammonia room which is attached to the chlorine building. All anhydrous ammonia equipment is located outside the facility. Piping delivers anhydrous ammonia vapor to the injectors. There is a Vacuum Regulator near the tank which drops the ammonia piping pressure to vacuum prior to entering the ammoniator. Injection of ammonia is controlled automatically using a flo

w control loop governed by the plant control system. There is an Ammonia Diffusion Tank located near the ammonia storage room. The Diffusion Tank allows for dumping of the ammonia tank contents in case of an emergency. The ammonia flow would be mixed with water and the resultant solution would be directed to the 10,000 gallon Diffusion Tank. The pressure relief valves from the Ammonia Tank also relieve to this location.



4. Offsite Consequence Analysis Results Summary



In developing the OCA, the approach followed the overall guidance provided by EPA in the RMP OCA Guidance (EPA Guidance) document (April, 1999). The worst-case release scenario and the alternative cases were evaluated using EPA RMP* Comp program. 



For chlorine, the worst-case scenario was defined to be the release of the entire vessel's contents over ten minutes in the absence of passive mitigation. This gave rise to a worst-case release rate of 200 lb/minute and a corresponding endpoint distance of 1.3 miles relative to an urban topography. There is an approximated population of 11,576 within the worst-case distance to endpoint about the Plant. The alternative release scenario was chosen as a release of chlorine from a 3/8" tubing. This would result in an average release rate of 27.83 lbs/minute over 60 minutes and a corresponding endpoint distance of 0.1 miles in urban topography. There is an estimated population of 0 within the alternate case distance to endpoint.



It is important to note that the worst-case release is extremely unlikely to occur, and it takes no credit for the many safety features inherent in the design and operation of the Plant that prevent such a release from happening. 



For the worst-case release of chlorine ever to occur, the following sequence of events would have to take place:



- A complete rupture of a chlorine container would have to occur.

- The entire contents of the vessel would have to be released within a time period of ten minutes.

- No operators wo

uld respond at any time to close off valves.

- The release would have to occur during the night or early morning at a time when the weather conditions would favor maximum downwind dispersion (Stability Class F and wind speed of 1.5 m/s).



It is extremely unlikely that this combination of events would ever occur in practice. On the other hand, the alternative release scenario is based on more credible assumptions. The alternative scenario was selected from a number of possible scenarios, based on their potential to reach offsite receptors. In reality, it is likely that any release that does occur would be less than that evaluated in the alternative scenario analysis. For example:



- It is more likely that the release would be a small leak from an orifice - such as a valve packing - rather than a 3/8 inch hole under pressure.

- The system is vacuum-based. Therefore, to get a release from a pressurized hole would require either a tank failure/cracking or tank valve failure or a vacuum regulator failure.

- The release could be terminated quickly if the operators respond quickly. The actual time could be less than the 60 minutes assumed.



5. Prevention Program Summary



Implementation of the Miramar Water Treatment Plant Prevention Program is another important consideration that helps to prevent a release or to minimize the impacts of a release that does occur. Some of the key elements that are incorporated into the Plant RMP/CalARP Prevention Program are summarized below. The prevention program is described in more detail in the Plant RMP/CalARP Manual Prevention Program section Process Safety Information. A comprehensive set of process safety information has been compiled for the chlorine and ammonia systems. The PSI includes data on the chemicals, the equipment, and the technology of the process.



Process Hazards Analysis. A PHA study was conducted on the chlorine and ammonia systems to evaluate potential hazards with the systems as designed. Recommendatio

ns were made by the PHA team to improve the safety of the systems. All safety recommendations are currently being implemented and records are being kept.



Operating Procedures. An Operations and Maintenance Manual provides detailed written operating procedures for the chlorine and anhydrous ammonia systems. Additional procedures are written for unloading chlorine and anhydrous ammonia.



Training. Training is provided to each operator and maintenance person before they are certified to operate the system.



Maintenance. All chlorine systems are included in the Plant maintenance program. Equipment inspections, testing and preventive maintenance activities are performed following a structured schedule.



Compliance Audits. A compliance audit procedure was developed for the CalARP program. It is updated every three years to verify compliance with CalARP regulations.



Incident Investigation. TVMWD routinely investigates any incident or accident that occurs at the Plant. The Plant has an Injury and Illness Prevention Program (IIPP) in place which defines how accidents and incidents are prevented at the Plant. The program addresses roles and responsibilities, safety inspections and audits, and safety training programs.



External Events Analysis. External events were considered in the PHA. Each external event with the potential to initiate a release was investigated in detail. A separate seismic study was also conducted and is included in the CalARP Manual.



6. Five-Year Accident History Summary

There have been no reportable near misses, minor accidents, or chlorine or anhydrous ammonia releases at the facility in the past five years.



7. Emergency Response Program Summary



The Plant emergency response program is described in the Emergency Response Plan for hazardous materials. The plan uses a systematic approach for the response based on the following two incident/emergency levels:



Incidental Release - A minor leak which occurs during normal operation a

nd maintenance activities. Such leaks can occur from a faulty gasket setting, a container valve packing gland problem, or a valve that is not seated properly. With this level of incident an operator or maintenance technician would be on hand to attend to the leak. Incidental releases are those that can be stopped quickly with routine O&M actions such as closing a valve or tightening a connection. For this reason, incidental releases are called "controlled releases".



Emergency Release - An uncontrolled leak that occurs within the chlorine system. An emergency release is an "uncontrolled release" that occurs within the chlorine system. This may occur when no staff is present in the building, or perhaps when a leak gets out of control. If an operator is present, the appropriate action would be to leave the area and initiate the emergency response plan notifications. This plan includes procedures for evacuations, notifying response agencies and adjacent businesses, emergency equipment list with maintenance schedule, and also for responding to each release level. The plan also includes first aid procedures for exposure to chlorine.



8. Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Nearly all PHA recommendations are being implemented concurrently with the submission of this RMP. It is Plant policy to review operating, maintenance, and emergency response procedures on a routine basis to ensure applicability. This continuous review process will generate further recommendations for improved safety during the course of operating the chlorine and anhydrous ammonia systems.



9. Summary



The design of the Plant chlorine facilities and the implementation of the Federal RMP and California Accidental Release Prevention Program provide a high level of assurance that the hazards and risks associated with the use of chlorine at the Plant are being managed in an appropriate manner. The likelihood of a release is minimized through the Plant's Risk Management Program.
